Prostaglandin Analogs.used_when: First-line choice for most patients with mild-to-moderate elevated IOP
Prostaglandin Analogs.action: Increases aqueous humor outflow through the uveoscleral pathway
Prostaglandin Analogs.why_chosen: High efficacy, once-daily dosing, minimal systemic side effects
Prostaglandin Analogs.limitations: May cause changes in iris color, not ideal for patients with a history of ocular inflammation
side_effects: Changes in eyelid or iris color

Beta Blockers.used_when: Second-line or adjunct when additional IOP reduction is needed
Beta Blockers.limitations: Not suitable for patients with respiratory or cardiac issues, twice-daily dosing often needed

Cholinergic Agents.used_when: Third-line or for cases with narrow-angle glaucoma
Cholinergic Agents.action: Increases aqueous outflow by contracting the ciliary muscle
Cholinergic Agents.why_chosen: Unique mechanism to increase aqueous outflow
Cholinergic Agents.limitations: Causes pupil constriction and blurry vision, affecting night vision
side_effects: Potentially increased risk of retinal detachment

Alpha-Adrenergic Agonists.used_when: Adjunct therapy, or for patients who cannot use beta blockers
Alpha-Adrenergic Agonists.action: Decreases aqueous humor production and increases outflow slightly
Alpha-Adrenergic Agonists.why_chosen: Dual action (reduces production and increases outflow), option for those with respiratory or heart issues
Alpha-Adrenergic Agonists.limitations: Can cause dry mouth, fatigue, and CNS side effects; requires twice-daily dosing

Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors.used_when: Third-line or for acute IOP reduction, e.g., acute angle-closure
Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors.action: Reduces aqueous humor production by inhibiting enzyme carbonic anhydrase
Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors.why_chosen: Strong IOP reduction, particularly effective in emergencies
Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors.limitations: Systemic side effects (especially oral), multiple doses needed if topical

Combined Medications.used_when: Advanced glaucoma cases needing robust IOP control, to simplify dosing
Combined Medications.action: Varies (usually combines two actions, e.g., reduce production + increase outflow)
Combined Medications.efficacy_potency: High; combines the effectiveness of two drugs for greater IOP reduction
Combined Medications.why_chosen: Increases adherence with fewer drops needed, combines effects of two agents
Combined Medications.limitations: Higher cost, may cause combined side effects, best suited for those tolerating both active drugs
side_effects: Combination of side effects from both medications in the formulation
Dry mouth and fatigue (if alpha-adrenergic agent is present)
